title: You've Been Trained to Depend on the System for Survival—Here's How to Break Free
summary: A foundational guide to reclaiming food sovereignty as the first step toward independence from extractive systems. Reveals how dependency isn't accidental—it's by design—and offers a practical 3-level off-ramp to rebuild food autonomy.

Food.summary: Reclaim food sovereignty through practical steps that reduce dependency on fragile supply chains.

level0: Do a pantry audit—identify what you actually use vs. what's marketing
Cook one more meal at home this week than usual
Shop intentionally: stick to outer edges of grocery store
Put a bowl by your sink tonight and start collecting compost scraps
level1: Choose shelf-stable items to 'buffer' each week (rice, beans, oats)
Learn to freeze leftovers and stretch ingredients
Try one new cooking skill: making stock, drying herbs, or baking bread
Start a simple compost system at home or find local drop-off
level2: Buy herbs or greens to grow on windowsill or patio
Join a CSA or find local farm box delivery
Swap or share food through Buy Nothing groups
Ask gardening neighbors about extra produce
level3: Set up container gardening for tomatoes, peppers, or potatoes
Connect with community gardens or permaculture meetups
Learn to identify one wild edible in your area
Build relationships with local farmers and food producers

Community.summary: Build food-sharing networks that create co-sufficiency rather than individual self-reliance.

level0: Join local Buy Nothing or food sharing groups
Offer to share a meal with neighbors
level1: Register on Make Soil to share compost scraps
Bring a dish made from neighbor's gifted produce
level2: Start or join a tool library for gardening equipment

Knowledge.summary: Rebuild basic food skills that have been outsourced to corporations.

resources.label: National Center for Home Food Preservation

level0: Learn to trust your senses while cooking instead of just following recipes
Understand which foods freeze well and how to store them
level1: Master batch cooking techniques: cook once, eat three times
Learn basic food preservation: freezing, drying, simple fermentation
level2: Develop intuitive cooking skills—listening to what food wants to do
Learn seasonal eating patterns for your region
level3: Study permaculture and regenerative growing methods
Master advanced preservation techniques: canning, smoking, root cellaring

Narrative.summary: Shift from 'convenience culture' to understanding food as a pathway to sovereignty.

level0: Recognize that food dependency isn't accidental—it's by design
Understand that 'convenience' often means giving up control
level1: Reframe cooking from burden to act of resistance
See composting as transformation rather than waste management
level2: Embrace 'preparedness as dignity' rather than paranoia
Understand co-sufficiency as more powerful than self-sufficiency
level3: Develop a vision of food systems that serve communities, not corporations
Share stories that inspire others to reclaim food sovereignty
